results.title: Game Masters: in conversation with Warren Spector
results.creator_credit: ACMI Public Programs and ACMI Content Development
results.brief_description:
Join Warren Spector, master of role playing game design, as he explores the ideas that have changed the gaming industry.
Spector is known for creating influential titles such as ‘System Shock’, ‘Deus Ex’, ‘Ultima Underworld’ and ‘Thief: The Dark Project’. His most recent release, ‘Disney Epic Mickey’, has been hailed as the embodiment of his renowned philosophy on videogame design.
This interview is a rare opportunity to hear from an industry legend, who has irrefutably influenced videogame theory and design. Filmed as part of the ACMI ‘Game Masters’ exhibtion 2012.

results.title: Game Masters: in conversation with Tim Schafer
results.creator_credit: ACMI Public Programs and ACMI Content Development
results.brief_description:
The expression “a Tim Schafer moment” is used among videogame experts and makers to describe an instance of great creativity or genius. This is a conversation with Tim Schafer, filmed as part of the ACMI ‘Game Masters’ exhibition 2012.

From studying computer science at the renowned UC Berkeley, to working at George Lucas’ game production company LucasArts, and finally to founding his own production company, Double Fine Productions, Tim Schafer has made an indelible mark on the international games industry.

Through his work on titles including ‘Maniac Mansion’, ‘The Secret of Monkey Island’ and ‘Full Throttle’, Schafer has became known for his storytelling and comedic style.

With the 1995 release of his highly acclaimed ‘Grim Fandango’, a noir adventure game set in the Aztec afterlife that draws its inspiration from the Mexican festival ‘Dia De Los Muertos’, Schafer cemented his place in games history and demonstrated the most momentous “Tim Schafer moment” of them all.

NB: Interviewer is neither seen nor heard onscreen.

results.title: Game in 21 points
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Clement Perron and Jacques Bobet
results.brief_description: Ping-Pong between two international champions, Denis Neale of Great Britain, and Jaroslav Stanek of Czechoslovakia. In this demonstration match the camera plays its own part in the action, often showing front-face views of the players simultaneously so that their amazing virtuosity and most telling shots may be observed without interruption. It is a sports film with a difference, and one that will prove as instructive to those already adept at the game as to novices. No spoken commentary.

results.title: Game hunting in the Arctic Regions (D)
results.brief_description: A silent documentary film with English subtitles, about an arctic sea voyage and game hunting in the north of Norway, and around Spitzbergen and Bear Island. WARNING: CONTAINS IMAGES OF DYING ANIMALS, BUTCHERING CARCASES AND CAGING WHICH MAY DISTURB SOME VIEWERS.

results.title: Gambling with our lives
results.brief_description: Modern technology provides us with an ever improving standard of living. However we are recognising the tradeoffs we must make between the benefits of progress against the potential hazards to our health. Research indicates that 85% of all cancer may be caused by environmental factors. This program looks into and discusses some of this research suggesting that we owe it to ourselves to learn more about the hazards of our modern world. Narrated by Norman Rose.

results.title: Galvani and Volta: an early debate in science)
results.creator_credit: Gilbert Altschul Productions and Journal Films
results.brief_description: Reviews Volta and Galvani’s early experiments in electro-chemistry. Uses experiments recreated in the physics laboratories in the University of Rome, the artifacts of Galvani’s and Volta’s laboratories, and the sketches and notes of their experiments to chronicle the great debate of Galvani and Volta on animal electricity vs bi-metallic electricity.

results.title: Gallipoli: The Anzac Legend
results.brief_description: The story of Gallipoli told by Robert Rhodes James, world renowned Gallipoli historian and surviving Anzac, and Turkish veterans of the campaign. Includes highlights of the 1990 return to Anzac Cove by Australian veterans and rare footage from Turkish archives.

results.title: Gallipoli: history in the depths = Derinlerdeki Tarih
results.creator_credit: B1R-TV, Asli Oymen, Keith McKennon and Sehbal Senyurt
results.brief_description: Presents an historical overview of the tragic circumstances which took place during the Gallipoli campaign in 1915 including a background profile of the lead-up to this most infamous battle. The Straits of the Dardanelles, a strategic key to the battle for Constantinople proved to be a watery graveyard for many Allied naval ships and cost the lives of over 500,000 soldiers from both the Allies and the Turks. A fatal mistake made by the Allies was to underestimate the determination and resourcefulness of the Turks who were prepared to defend their land at all costs. Covers in detail, the assault on the Gallipoli Peninsula by the ANZACs on 25 April 1915 through to the final decision by the British to withdraw on 7 December 1915. One poignant moment stands out in this horrific account of the Gallipoli campaign - on 24 May 1915, a ceasefire was called and both the ANZACs and the Turkish soldiers worked together to bury their dead (numbering in thousands). For just a moment the two sides came together in mutual respect and admiration for each other as soldiers, even parting on friendly terms before finally being ordered back into battle against each other once more. A thread running through the documentary is the battleships lost at sea. Underwater photography of the remains of many of these ships is included. Also includes stills, newsreel and archival film footage, and a detailed retelling through the words of historians, experts and the actual soldiers who fought in the Gallipoli campaign. Narrated by David Ritchie. Teacher notes included. Suitable for middle secondary level. Note: This is the English version produced by SBS Australia in 2001.

results.title: Gallipoli: a virtual tour (MAC & PC)
results.brief_description: A highly visual interactive document on the First World War Gallipoli campaign. Containing hundreds of images, documents, music and various footage from 1915 makes this virtual tour ideal for schools. This CD-ROM is broken up into various historical aspects and is set up to play on both PC and Mac computers - all you need is a web browser such as Internet Explorer or Netscape. For PC users, Internet Explorer 5 can be installed from the CD.
